DOC.HEAD: Baker Discusses Different Supports for Democracy
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON (AM) _ The Soviet Union is supporting democracy by not interfering in other countries while the United States, this time, is supporting democracy by sending troops into another country, Secretary of State James A. Baker III noted Wednesday. In discussing the Soviet criticism of the U.S. attack on the forces of dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Baker said: ``Let me say that I think both the United States and the Soviet Union today are supporting democracy. At least that's what President Gorbachev told President Bush at Malta when he said he had a little problem with the use of the word democratic _ I mean, `Western values,' so we agreed that we would you use the term `democratic values.' ``The difference is that the Soviet Union supports democracy by staying out of countries and thus permitting democracy to proceed. In this one and very unique instance, the United States did it by going in to assist a democratically elected government against a dictator.'' There have been many reports from Eastern Europe crediting Gorbachev's refusal to support local Communist parties for the dramatic emergence of non-Communist governments in several capitals. Noriega overturned the results of an election this year in which Panama citizens voted for Guillermo Endara for president on May 7. Noriega-formed ``Dignity Battalions'' beat opposition candidates in the streets.
